questions.question_text: Which two SD-WAN load balancing methods use interface weight value to distribute traffic?

comments.content: Just saw - on 6.0 Weight method is actually named Sessions...

discussion.content:
Correct B and D, Infrastructure 6.2 - p.72
I believe they meant Weight and Volume
Weight - Traffic will be distributed based on weights assigned on interfaces
Volume - Sessions are distributed so that traffic volume is distributed by the interface weights.
Spillover is wrong - Use one interface until threshold is reached
Source IP is wrong - Sessions from the same IP address uses the same interface

questions.question_text: What three FortiGate components are tested during the hardware test? (Choose three.)
Which certificate value can FortiGate use to determine the relationship between the issuer and the certificate?

discussion.content: A. is correct Subject Key Identifier value

Selected Answer: A
FortiGate can use the Subject Key Identifier, and Authority Key Identifier values to determine the relationship between the issuer of the certificate (identified in the Issuer field), and the certificate.

Reference: FortiGate 7.4 Administrator Study Guide, page 162.

Selected Answer: A
A. is correct
A should be the correct answer, Subject Key Identifier value

A. IS CORRECT. FortiGate can use the Subject Key Identifier and Authority Key Identifier values to determine the relationship between the issuer of the certificate (identified in the Issuer field) and the certificate. FGT_Security-6.2, p. 316

questions.question_text: Why must you use aggressive mode when a local FortiGate IPsec gateway hosts multiple dialup tunnels?

choices.A: Main mode does not support XAuth for user authentication.
choices.C: FortiGate is able to handle NATed connections only in aggressive mode.
choices.B: In aggressive mode, the remote peers are able to provide their peer IDs in the first message.
It represents the number of objects used in the firewall policy.
choices.A: It is required to modify a firewall policy using the CLI.
choices.C: It changes when firewall policies are reordered.
choices.D: It defines the order in which rules are processed.
